entry.title: Royal Mint is giving coins to 75 people turning 75, to mark the King’s birthday
entry.summary: A new commemorative coin celebrating the King’s 75th birthday and paying tribute to his passion for the natural world has been unveiled by the Royal Mint. To mark the occasion, the Mint is looking for 75 people turning 75 years old this year, to give them a special £5 coin, in honour of the King’s birthday. To honour the King’s lifelong commitment to sustainability, a special birthday coin has also been made from a blend of silver recovered from industrial and medical x-ray films. Those celebrating their 75th birthday in 2023 can submit their name and contact details via the Royal Mint to be in with a chance of receiving an uncirculated £5 commemorative coin. The winners will be drawn at random and asked to provide photographic evidence of age. They will be contacted via email from early December 2023.

entry.title: Newspoll: Peter Dutton overtakes Anthony Albanese on the primary vote
entry.summary:
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has gained a considerable amount of ground over Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, according to the latest Newspoll.
In the first major poll since the Voice referendum was defeated, the Coalition now leads Labor on the primary vote.
The poll reports the primary vote for the Coalition is at 37 per cent whilst Labor trails behind now at 35 per cent.
On two-party preferred voting the Coalition has also tightened the gap at 48 per cent, coming in close to Labor’s 52 per cent.
This latest data has marked the closest contest since the election.

entry.title: Israel launches deadliest attack yet to destroy Hamas
entry.summary:
Massive explosions are hitting Gaza City and its surroundings as Israel continues on with its deadliest campaign to destroy Hamas following the terrorist group's unprovoked attack on October 7.
The IDF on Sunday said its troops were “encircling Gaza city” and conducting “widespread strikes”.
Health officials in the Palestinian territory claimed 53 people died in two blasts at refugee camps.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reaffirmed his rejection for a ceasefire on Sunday until the some 240 hostages taken by Hamas on October 7 are released.
"There will be no ceasefire without the return of the hostages. This should be completely removed from the lexicon," Mr Netanyahu said.
"We say this to our friends and to our enemies. We will simply continue until we defeat them. We have no alternative."

entry.title: Pro-Palestinian Protesters Try To Storm Air Base Housing U.S. Troops In Turkey
entry.summary:
Using gas bombs and water cannons, Turkish security forces disperse thousands demonstrating outside the US military base of İncirlik in Adana province in protest of the Israeli genocide campaign in Gaza. pic.twitter.com/nvH6mWxljM — Quds News Network (@QudsNen) November 5, 2023
Reuters: Pro-Palestinian crowds try to storm air base housing U.S. troops in Turkey ADANA, Turkey (Reuters) - Turkish police used tear gas and water cannon as hundreds of people at a pro-Palestinian rally on Sunday tried to storm an air base that houses U.S. troops, hours before U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken was due in Ankara for talks on Gaza. Turkey, which has stepped up its criticism of Israel as the humanitarian crisis in Gaza has worsened, supports a two-state solution while hosting members of the Palestinian militant group Hamas. Since the Israel-Hamas war started, protests have erupted across the country. Earlier this week, the IHH Humanitarian Relief Foundation, an Islamist Turkish aid agency, organised a convoy to travel to the Incirlik air base in the Adana province in southern Turkey to protest Israeli attacks on Gaza and U.S. support for Israel.
Read more .... Update: Turkish police tear gas pro-Palestinian protesters at air base (France 24)
WNU Editor: It should be noted that this base also houses nuclear weapons .... What Biden said about nuclear weapons at İncirlik base and what he can do (Hurriyet Daily News).

Reynolds will appear at a DeSantis rally in Iowa on Monday. DeSantis has focused heavily on Iowa, believing a strong showing in the state could help him close the gap with Trump. The Trump campaign responded to the endorsement news by criticizing Reynolds for previously declaring neutrality in the race.

entry.summary: More than 20 people were killed in Sudan after shells hit a market in a suburb of the capital, Khartoum. The fighting between army chief Abdel Fattah al-Burhan and his former deputy Mohamed Hamdan Daglo has been ongoing since April. The conflict has resulted in over 10,000 deaths and 5.5 million people being displaced, according to estimates by the United Nations. The actual toll is believed to be higher as many of the wounded and killed do not reach hospitals or morgues.

entry.title: China’s fintech dilemma — beloved by small business, distrusted by regulators
entry.summary: China’s small business owners have welcomed the rise of financial platforms more suited to their needs, but those platforms’ attendant risk has made them something of a liability for a risk-averse government. entry.title: Why Are So Many U.S. Artillery Gun Crews Who Were Deployed To Bombard The Islamic State Facing Health And Psychological Issues?
entry.summary:
U.S. soldiers assigned to 1st Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division, fire their M777 A2 Howitzer in Syria on Sept. 30, 2021. (Cpl. Isaiah Scott/Army) DNYUZ/New York Times: A Secret War, Strange New Wounds, and Silence From the Pentagon When Javier Ortiz came home from a secret mission in Syria, the ghost of a dead girl appeared to him in his kitchen. She was pale and covered in chalky dust, as if hit by an explosion, and her eyes stared at him with a glare as dark and heavy as oil. The 21-year-old Marine was part of an artillery gun crew that fought against the Islamic State, and he knew that his unit’s huge cannons had killed hundreds of enemy fighters. The ghost, he was sure, was their revenge. A shiver went through him. He backed into another room in his apartment near Camp Pendleton in California and flicked on the lights, certain that he was imagining things. She was still there.
Read more .... WNU Editor: This story hits close to home. My father commanded artillery units for the Soviet Army during the Second World War. Aside from suffering hearing loss, he was haunted by nightmares from that war for the rest of his life. My father's best friend (and my Godfather) also served in such a unit, and he committed suicide 20 years after the war. Everyone blamed his war experience for his suicide.

entry.title: Ohio vote tests abortion question one year ahead of 2024 race
entry.summary: Ohio voters will decide on Tuesday whether to add explicit protections for abortion rights to the state's constitution. The referendum will determine whether the constitution guarantees the freedom to make reproductive decisions, including abortion. The US Supreme Court revoked the national right to abortion last year, leaving it up to individual states to decide. Ohio currently has a law that would ban abortions after a heartbeat is detected, but it is temporarily suspended due to legal challenges.

entry.title: In rift with military, Zelensky slams top gen for 'war at stalemate' remark
entry.summary: The office of President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday chastised Ukraine's top military commander for publicly declaring the war at a stalemate, suggesting the comments would help the Russian invasion. It was a striking public rebuke that signaled an emerging rift between the military and civilian leadership at a challenging time for Ukraine. The public censure of Zaluzhny came a day after the president's office replaced one of his deputies, the head of special operations forces, who after his firing said he had been blindsided by the dismissal.

entry.title: Anger against Netanyahu rises as Israelis amass outside his home
entry.summary: Protesters gathered outside the residence of Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu to express their anger at the failures that led to last month's deadly attack by Hamas gunmen. The protest coincided with a poll showing that over three-quarters of Israelis believe Netanyahu should resign. Netanyahu has not taken personal responsibility for the failures that allowed the surprise assault, which has led to growing public fury and criticism of the government's response. A majority of Israelis blame Netanyahu for the attack, according to the poll.

entry.title: Hostage crisis at German airport ends after 18 hrs
entry.summary: A hostage situation at Hamburg airport in Germany came to an end after 18 hours. The man, who had driven his vehicle through the gates with his 4-year-old daughter inside, was arrested and the girl is unharmed. The airport had been closed since Saturday night when the armed man broke through a gate and fired shots. The man's wife had previously reported a child abduction, and it is believed to be a custody battle. No one was injured during the standoff.

entry.title: Trump leads in 5 of 6 key battleground US states as voters blast Biden: Polls
entry.summary: President Biden is trailing behind Donald Trump in five out of six battleground states, according to polls by the New York Times and Siena College. Voters have doubts about Biden's age and are dissatisfied with his handling of the economy and other issues. Biden is only ahead in Wisconsin, while Trump leads in Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, and Pennsylvania. The polls also show that voters across income levels feel Biden's policies have hurt them personally, while they credit Trump's policies for helping them.

entry.title: How Is The Russian Economy Doing?
entry.summary:
BNN: Russia’s Economy to Grow by 2.8% in 2023, Predicts Finance Minister Anticipating a more robust financial year ahead, Russia’s Finance Minister Anton Siluanov has forecasted a 2.8 percent expansion in Russia’s GDP in 2023, a significant bounce-back from a 2 percent contraction experienced in the previous year. Siluanov attributes this hopeful outlook to full compensation for last year’s decrease and the stabilization of the ruble exchange rate. Rebound from Economic Contraction The predicted growth in Russia’s economy marks a recovery from the challenging economic climate of 2022 when the nation grappled with a 2 percent economic decline. Siluanov, however, projects a promising 2.8 to 3 percent expansion in the upcoming year, viewing it as a reparation for the previous year’s downturn.
Read more ....
Update #1: Russia's economic situation develops steadily – Putin (TASS)
Update #2: Russia brings back capital controls to shore up the ruble (CNN)
WNU Editor: The Western media likes to focus on the rise and fall and rise of the Russian ruble, but the Russian economy is more than just that. So here is my recap. The civilian economy is booming and it is causing problems (inflation, labor shortages, etc.). And as for that part of the economy that is dedicated to military production .... I cannot even express in words on how huge of an impact that is having on the economy as a whole. But the big story on the Russia economy that many in the West have not caught up on is the Kremlin's priority to re-industrialize the country. I know the money is there to make it happen, but the big problem that I see will be having the workers to make this all happen. Update #3: The Duran's analysis on the Russian economy (see below) concurs with what I know is happening in Russia.

entry.title: Blinken says Palestinian voices key to Gaza future
entry.summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has stated that the Palestinian Authority should have a central role in the future of Gaza. Blinken made the comments during his visit to the region amid escalating tensions over Israel's war with Hamas. He met with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas in Ramallah and then traveled to Iraq. Blinken also discussed the need for humanitarian pauses in the fighting and addressed the threats from Iranian-aligned militias. He is seeking discussions on how Gaza could be governed after the destruction of Hamas.

President Joe Biden has called for a pause in hostilities to allow hostages to be released, and the White House supports a humanitarian pause for aid deliveries to Gaza. Over 9,770 Palestinians have been killed in the conflict.

The clashes between Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants along the Lebanon-Israel border have been escalating since the start of the Hamas-Israel war. The death toll of civilians on the Lebanese side has now reached 14, with Hezbollah warning of retaliation if Lebanese civilians are targeted.

entry.title: The Growing Sentiment In Ukraine Is That They Are Losing The War
entry.summary:
This photograph taken on November 3, 2023, shows the Motherland Monument, a 62-meter Soviet-era statue, through the trees in Kyiv. (Sergei SUPINSKY)
AFP: 'We're losing': Ukrainians reel from war chief's stalemate warning In eastern Ukraine, where another gruelling winter is descending -- along with it a likely freeze in major frontline movements -- one Ukrainian soldier had a grim assessment of the conflict. The 35-year-old fighting near the war-battered town of Bakhmut went further than comments from Ukraine's most senior military official, who conceded this week that the war with Russia had reached a stalemate. "I've been saying that for some time now already. Step by step we're losing the war," the serviceman, who uses the call sign "Mudryi" (Wise), told AFP. "The longer this static war continues, the worse it is for us," he said in a phone interview.
Read more .... WNU Editor: The above AFP news report is a sober read and confirms what I have been hearing. The failure of the counter-offensive to break the Russian lines coupled with tens of thousands of casualties has stunned everyone I know in Ukraine. They expected at least some advances. They certainly never expected a stalemate nor Russian advances in the northeastern part of the country.

entry.summary: Four Palestinians were killed during Israeli military raids in the occupied West Bank, according to the Palestinian health ministry and Israeli army. The violence occurred amidst the Israel-Hamas war. Two men were killed in an attack by Israeli forces in Abu Dis, while a third Palestinian, allegedly affiliated with the Islamic State group, was shot dead in a fire exchange. Another Palestinian was killed in Nuba during clashes with Israeli soldiers. Since the start of the war, over 150 Palestinians have been killed in the West Bank, and over 1,000 have been arrested.

entry.title: Internet, phone lines cut again in Gaza: Telecoms firm
entry.summary: Israel cut internet and phone lines in the Gaza Strip Sunday night, for the third time since the start of the Israel-Hamas war on October 7, telecoms firm Paltel said. "We regret to announce the complete shutdown of communications and internet services in Gaza after the Israeli side disconnected the servers," Paltel said in a statement. However, soon Israeli army launched intense bombardment on Gaza city and other nearby zones which could be heard in Rafah.

entry.title: Ukraine President Zelensky Rebukes Top General Over ‘Stalemate’ Comments
entry.summary:
© Photo : Ukrainian President's Office
Kyiv Post: Zelensky’s Office Issues Warning After Zaluzhny’s ‘Stalemate’ Interview President Zelensky's deputy chief-of-staff suggested that military officials should perhaps keep quiet about the situation on the front lines, lest they give the Russians an advantage. Ihor Zhovkva, Deputy Head of the President's Office, has advised military officials against publicly disclosing sensitive information about the situation at the front lines. Zhovkva's comments came in response to an interview with Valery Zaluzhny, the Commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, for The Economist. The interview also contained a link to a lengthy essay by Zaluzhny replete with military assessments. The deputy chief-of-staff suggested that by making comments "we make it easier for the aggressor to work."
Read more ....
WNU Editor: There is a lot of doom and gloom coming from my contacts/friends/and family members in Ukraine right now. I am not surprised to see this pessimistic mood now in the upper echelons of the Ukraine government. Ukraine President Zelensky Rebukes Top General Over ‘Stalemate’ Comments

entry.title: US envoy to Israel submits credentials to Pres Herzog, takes charge
entry.summary: Israeli President Isaac Herzog accepted the credentials of newly appointed US Ambassador to Israel Jack Lew. The appointment was fast-tracked due to the escalating conflict between Hamas and Israel in Gaza. During the credential-receiving ceremony, President Herzog expressed gratitude for the support of the United States and emphasized the importance of the friendship between the two countries. Ambassador Lew acknowledged the challenging times and pledged to prioritize working towards securing the release of hostages held by Hamas.

entry.title: 'Israeli spies' held in joint operation with Afghanistan: Iran
entry.summary: Three Iranians who were allegedly agents of Israel's Mossad spy agency have been detained in a joint operation with the Taliban in Afghanistan, according to state television in Iran. It said that the detainees were said to be planning kamikaze drone attacks from the Afghan border into Iran. News of the arrests came after a Taliban delegation arrived in Tehran on Saturday for meetings with top officials including Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian.

entry.title: New Russian Nuclear Submarine Test Launches A Bulava Intercontinental Missile
entry.summary:
RT: Russian ballistic missile hits target thousands of kilometers away (VIDEO) A Bulava ICBM has successfully reached Kamchatka after being launched from the White Sea, the Defense Ministry has said A Russian nuclear-powered submarine has conducted a ballistic missile test, with the projectile traveling several thousand kilometers from the northern to the easternmost part of the country, the Defense Ministry has said. In a statement in the early hours of Sunday, the ministry said that the submarine ‘Emperor Alexander III’ had “successfully launched the Bulava sea-based intercontinental ballistic missile from the White Sea to the Kura test range on the Kamchatka Peninsula.” It added that the missile was fired underwater and that its warheads reached the target on time.
Read more ....

entry.title: U.S. Army In A Rush To Train Recruiters
entry.summary:
U.S. Army Lt. Col. Richard A. Montcalm gives the Oath of Enlistment, April 18, 2023, at the Douthit Gunnery Complex on Fort Riley, Kansas. (U.S. Army photo by Sgt. Jared Simmons)
Military.com: The Army Suddenly, and Chaotically, Told Hundreds of Soldiers They Have to Be Recruiters Immediately Without warning, hundreds of noncommissioned officers were ordered via email to report to the recruiting school at Fort Knox, Kentucky, in less than a week, with hundreds more set to start at the school in December -- a sudden unexpected move by the Army as the service scrambles to boost its recruiting force by 800 by the end of the year. The orders came after a breakdown in how the Army tracks how many recruiters it has coming through the pipeline along with retention of existing ones, according to Lt. Gen. Douglas Stitt, the Army's top personnel officer. The sudden depletion of recruiters caught Army planners flat-footed, with officials unable to provide a clear explanation as to what went wrong. Now, NCOs will likely have to move during the holiday season and in the middle of the school year, sowing chaos for families.
Read more ....
WNU Editor: Why the rush to have recruiters? Why the rush for new soldiers? If this does not work-out, is a U.S. draft next? You tell me.

entry.title: Stories behind Day of the Dead
entry.summary: Every November, Mexico holds its largest public celebration: Día de los Muertos, a fusion of Roman Catholic and Indigenous rituals that honor and remember deceased loved ones. Far from a mournful affair, the holiday is a time of celebration and warmth.

entry.title: Mexico's Day of the Dead celebrations
entry.summary: Every November 1st and 2nd, Mexico holds its largest public celebration: Día de los Muertos, or Day of the Dead, a fusion of Roman Catholic and Indigenous rituals that honor and remember deceased loved ones. Far from a mournful affair, the holiday is a time of celebration and warmth. Correspondent Enrique Acevedo talks with Mexico City's minister of culture Claudia Curiel De Icaza about the city's celebrations; with acclaimed chef Elena Reygadas about baking traditional pan de muerto; and with author Regina Marchi, who has documented the holiday's growing popularity on both sides of the border in her book, "Day of the Dead in the U.S.A."

entry.title: Has Ukraine Received Shipments Of F-16s?
entry.summary:
FILE - Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte walk past an F-16 fighter jet in Eindhoven, Netherlands, Aug. 20, 2023.
Bulgarian Military: Trucks brought two dismantled F-16s to Ukraine from Poland – Rybar Rybar, a Russian think tank, asserts that two disassembled F-16s were transported into Ukraine from Poland on the night of November 3. The organization further reports that since the beginning of November, there has been an influx of no less than five dismantled F-16s into Ukrainian territories, inclusive of the two aforementioned jets delivered on November 3rd. In a recent delivery update shared on his X account [which was once Twitter], Rybar informs his followers that “the eagerly anticipated shipment is now in possession,” referencing the arrival of two F-16 jets delivered via truck transportation.
Read more ....
WNU Editor: There are reasons to believe that Ukraine is already receiving these jets. For one, the Dutch Prime Mminister said last week that F-16s are going to be delivered to Romania for shipment to Ukraine within two weeks .... Dutch Prime Minister: F-16s for Ukraine to Arrive in Romania Within Two Weeks (VOA/Reuters), and Ukrainian pilots are already being trained to use these jets .... entry.title: U.S. Developing A New Nuclear Gravity Bomb
entry.summary:
The Pentagon has announced plans for a new nuclear bomb 24 times as powerful as the one dropped on Hiroshima in 1945. It comes days after it emerged China plans to double its arsenal of nuclear warheads to over 1,000 by 2030
Daily Mail: Maps show devastating impact of America's new super-nuke on Russian capital: B61-13 'gravity bomb' has 24 times more power than the one dropped on Hiroshima * The Biden administration is developing a new nuclear bomb - the B61-13 has the potential to cause significant devastation in Moscow * Simulation of bomb's estimated maximum yield of 360 kilotons of TNT could see many deaths with more than 300,000 killed and hundreds of thousands injured * Development of the weapon is primarily intended as a deterrent and to provide assurance to allies Maps have been released depicting the destruction that could be unleashed should a new type of nuclear bomb being developed by the Biden Administration be dropped on Moscow. The Pentagon announced this week that it is developing a new nuclear 'gravity bomb' that is 24 times more powerful than the nuke detonated in Hiroshima. The B61-13 is the 13th variant of the B61 family of 'gravity bombs,' which fall to their target rather than being guided. Read more .... U.S. Is Developing A New Nuclear Gravity Bomb

entry.summary: The Israeli army said Sunday its land assault on the Gaza Strip had split the Palestinian territory in two, with "significant" strikes continuing in its war against Hamas. Israeli airstrikes hit two refugee camps in the central Gaza Strip on Sunday, killing at least 45 people, the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza said. The strikes came as US Secretary of State Antony Blinken continued his Middle-eastern tour with an unannounced visit to Iraq, as Washington tries to prevent a regional spillover. Tensions increased with neighbouring Lebanon as an Israeli strike in the south of the country killed three children and their grandmother, Lebanese authorities said. Follow our live blog for the latest updates. All times are Paris time (GMT+1).

entry.title: Ukraine President Zelensky Says The Israeal - Hamas War Is 'Taking Away Focus' From Ukraine
entry.summary:
Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky (R) greets European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen (L) in Kyiv on November 4, 2023. European Commission President arrived in Kyiv to discuss Ukraine's accession to the EU with Ukrainian President. © Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, Handout via AFP France 24: Gaza conflict 'taking away focus' from Ukraine, Zelensky says
President Volodymyr Zelensky denied on Saturday that Ukraine's war with Russia had reached a "stalemate", pushing back at suggestions Western leaders were lobbying for peace talks. The sprawling frontline between the two warring sides has barely moved in almost a year, with one senior Ukrainian official warning this week that the conflict was deadlocked. "Time has passed, people are tired... But this is not a stalemate," Zelensky told a press conference in Kyiv with EU Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen. The Ukrainian leader also rejected the idea Western countries were putting pressure on Kyiv to enter negotiations with Russia, amid reports US and EU officials had discussed what such talks would entail.
Read more ....
Update #1: Ukraine war: Zelensky says Israel-Gaza conflict taking focus away from fighting (BBC).

entry.title: Fighting Intensifies Between Myanmar's Junta And Ethnic Rebel Groups Near The Shared Border With China
entry.summary:
ABC News Australia/AFP: Fighting between Myanmar's junta and ethnic rebel groups near shared border with China displaces thousands Thousands of people are newly displaced, with some crossing into China, as fighting intensifies between Myanmar's junta and ethnic rebel groups in areas near the border. The junta launched a second day of air strikes on Wednesday, bombing territory in the northernmost Kachin state controlled by ethnic armed group Kachin Independence Army (KIA), a rebel spokesperson told AFP. Since Friday, the junta also has been battling an alliance of ethnic rebel groups across the neighbouring north-eastern Shan state.

entry.title: Pentagon Says There Are No Limits On How Israel Uses U.S. Weapons
entry.summary:
Deputy Pentagon Press Secretary Sabrina Singh Conducts Press Briefing. Photo by Petty Officer 2nd Class Alexander Kubitza Business Insider: Pentagon says there are no limits on how Israel uses US weapons as death toll climbs amid airstrikes in Gaza * The Pentagon says there are no limits on how Israel uses US-provided weapons in their attacks in Gaza. * A spokesperson said it's up to the IDF how it uses the weapons. * Israeli airstrikes have devastated the Gaza Strip, and a new ground offensive could do further damage. The US is not putting any limits on how Israel uses US-provided weapons in its bloody war against Hamas that has killed thousands of Palestinian civilians and destroyed parts of the Gaza Strip, the Pentagon says as the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) ramps up its retaliatory attacks in the area. On Monday, Deputy Pentagon Press Secretary Sabrina Singh told that "we are not putting any limits on how Israel uses weapons that [are] provided," Voice of America National Security Correspondent Jeff Seldin reported. "We're not putting any constraints on that," she said.
Read more ....

entry.title: Hezbollah Targets Israel With 'Volcano' Rockets
entry.summary:
“Burkan” Volcano Rockets
Newsweek: Hezbollah Targets Israel With 'Volcano' Rockets as Tensions Soar The militant group Hezbollah launched missile strikes against Israel on Saturday using rockets dubbed "The Volcano," as tensions continue to soar along the country's northern border with Lebanon. The Associated Press reported Saturday that Israel had launched airstrikes along the Lebanese border, as Hezbollah carried out several strikes of its own against Israeli military sites. One of these Israeli sites, known in Lebanon as Jal al-Allam, was struck by two large Burkan missiles, according to the AP. Translated as "volcano" in Arabic, Burkan missiles have an operational range of 500-2,000 meters and are outfitted with sizeable warheads that can weigh hundreds of kilograms.
Read more .... Hezbollah Targets Israel With 'Volcano' Rockets Hezbollah launches ‘volcano' rockets targeting Israeli military sites -- Express

Israel launched airstrikes on multiple Hezbollah positions near the Lebanese border as the Iran-backed militant group launched rockets towards Israeli targets, the Associated Press reported.
Hezbollah has repeatedly threatened escalation amid Israel’s war with Hamas, an ally of the group, in Gaza. “What the Israelis do to Lebanon will also determine how we will act,” leader Hassan Nasrallah said Friday. “All options are on the table on the Lebanese front.” Read more .... entry.title: New Report Says Democracy 'In Trouble' Across The World
entry.summary:
Politico.eu: Democracy in decline worldwide, new report says
Orbán, Trump and Erdoğan contribute to continuing downturn around the globe. The bedrock of democracy is trembling amid a surge of authoritarianism around the world, according to a report published Thursday. Hard-line rule by current and former leaders, including Viktor Orbán in Hungary, Donald Trump in the U.S. and Recep Tayyip Erdoğan in Turkey, has contributed to the downturn observed in the past few years, the Global State of Democracy 2023 report by the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (IDEA) has said. Read more ....
WNU Editor: According to this report, civil liberties and judicial independence are under threat in 85 democratic countries. The report is here .... Bedrocks of democracy under threat across the globe (IDEA). New Report Says Democracy 'In Trouble' Across The World

entry.title: U.S. And European Officials Exploring The Possibility Of Peace Negotiations With Russia To End The War
entry.summary:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy arrives to address the 78th United Nations General Assembly in September.Timothy A. Clary / AFP NBC: U.S., European officials broach topic of peace negotiations with Ukraine, sources say
The conversations have included very broad outlines of what Ukraine might need to give up to reach a deal with Russia. WASHINGTON — U.S. and European officials have begun quietly talking to the Ukrainian government about what possible peace negotiations with Russia might entail to end the war, according to one current senior U.S. official and one former senior U.S. official familiar with the discussions. The conversations have included very broad outlines of what Ukraine might need to give up to reach a deal, the officials said. Some of the talks, which officials described as delicate, took place last month during a meeting of representatives from more than 50 nations supporting Ukraine, including NATO members, known as the Ukraine Defense Contact Group, the officials said. The discussions are an acknowledgment of the dynamics militarily on the ground in Ukraine and politically in the U.S. and Europe, officials said.
Read more ....
WNU Editor: Good luck on that. Ukraine President Zelensky and the people around him have made it very clear on what their conditions are to end the war, and those conditions are not even remotely close to what the US and the EU are proposing.

entry.title: Canadian Main Stream Media Finally Reporting On Ukraine's Dire Military Situation In The War
entry.summary:
Photo : La Presse canadienne / Nathan Denette
CTV: Exhausted and disappointed with allies, Ukraine's president and military chief warn of long attritional war Two articles published this week give a stark assessment of Ukraine’s prospects in its war with Russia. One – by the commander in chief of the Ukrainian military – admits the battlefield has reached a stalemate and a long attritional war benefiting Moscow beckons. The other portrays Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky as exhausted by the constant effort to cajole and persuade allies to keep the faith. Ukraine’s military chief, Gen. Valery Zaluzhny, says in a long essay and interview with the Economist that “just like in the First World War we have reached the level of technology that puts us into a stalemate.” He acknowledges: “There will most likely be no deep and beautiful breakthrough,” but instead an equilibrium of devastating losses and destruction. Read more ....
WNU Editor: The two articles the above CTV news report is focused on are .... Time - Ukraine President Zelensky ‘Feels Betrayed’ By The West (October 31, 2023) and Top Ukrainian General’s Pessimistic View On The War Fuels A Debate In The U.S. Congress On Providing Military Aid (November 2, 2023).

entry.title: In global employee well-being survey, India second after Turkiye; Japan last
entry.summary: Japan came in last in a global ranking of employees' well being, measured by assessing physical, mental, social and spiritual health, the results of a survey conducted by McKinsey health institute showed. The island nation scored 25% in the poll of more than 30,000 workers across 30 countries, according to the study. Turkiye was highest at 78%, followed by 76% for India and 75% for China. The global average was 57%. According to the survey, employees who had positive work experiences reported better holistic health, are more innovative at work and show higher job performance.

entry.title: FTX crypto mogul convicted of fraud, faces max of 110 yrs in jail
entry.summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX cryptocurrency exchange, has been convicted of fraud by a New York jury. The jury found him guilty of stealing at least $10 billion from customers and investors. Bankman-Fried, once worth over $20 billion, is now facing a maximum sentence of 110 years. The conviction is a significant victory for US attorney Damian Williams, who described Bankman-Fried's actions as "one of the biggest financial frauds in US history." Bankman-Fried is expected to appeal the verdict.

entry.title: Wagner to give Hezbollah air defence system? Kremlin dismisses report
entry.summary: The Kremlin on Friday dismissed a Wall Street Journal report that United States intelligence believed Russia's Wagner mercenary group plans to provide Hezbollah with an air defence system, saying such talk was unfounded. "We have already said that, de-facto, such a group (Wagner) does not exist," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. "All of these musings are as a rule based on nothing and have no foundation," Peskov said when asked about the report.

Blinken has emphasized the need for Israel to protect Palestinian civilians in Gaza. The US has dismissed international calls for a ceasefire but has sought to persuade Israel to accept localized pauses.

entry.title: Mark Zuckerberg undergoes surgery for martial arts knee injury
entry.summary: Meta Platforms Inc. Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg underwent surgery to repair a torn knee ligament sustained during a mixed martial arts session, he said Friday in a post on Instagram. “Tore my ACL sparring and just got out of surgery to replace it,” Zuckerberg wrote in the caption of a post with a series of photos showing him in a hospital bed, his knee bandaged and in a brace. The CEO, 39, said he plans to continuing his training for “a competitive MMA fight early next year.”

entry.title: Maine mass shooter was alive for most of massive 2-day search, autopsy suggests
entry.summary: The Army reservist who carried out the shootings in a bowling alley and a bar in Lewiston, Maine, was alive and potentially on the run for more than 24 hours after the incident, according to the state's medical examiner. Robert Card died from a self-inflicted gunshot, which likely occurred eight to 12 hours before his body was found in a tractor-trailer. Concerns about Card's mental state had been raised prior to the shootings, and law enforcement agencies came under scrutiny for not finding his body sooner.

entry.title: North Korean art sells in China despite UN sanctions over nuclear programme
entry.summary: A Chinese art gallery, The Paintings Say Arirang, is openly selling North Korean art in Beijing, despite UN sanctions prohibiting such sales. The gallery, which operates a studio for North Korean artists, showcases the unique socialist realist style of North Korean art that appeals to a niche audience. China's lax enforcement of the sanctions targeting North Korea's nuclear program allows for the continued sale of North Korean art. The art is seen as a form of propaganda, with artists working directly for North Korea's authorities to create art glorifying the state and its ideology.

entry.title: Solar storm causes pumpkin-colored auroras to fill sky
entry.summary: A recent solar storm caused a unique combination of red and green lights in the night sky above Canada, creating a strange image of orange pillars. Experts say that orange auroras shouldn't exist as the color is usually overwhelmed by other colors given off by excited molecules. The phenomenon was captured in a photograph by aurora photographer Harlan Thomas, who described the orange hue as "sublime." The last time such vibrant orange auroras were seen was during the Halloween storm of 2003.

entry.summary: For Gaza's two million residents, the Rafah border with Egypt serves as a vital lifeline. Over the years, this crossing has seen numerous shifts, openings, and closures, prompting the construction of illicit tunnels beneath it to facilitate the flow of people and goods. As the war between Israel and Hamas persists, the Rafah border now plays a crucial role in evacuations and the delivery of humanitarian aid.

entry.title: Argentina: Unpalatable Choices in Election Plagued with Uncertainty
entry.summary:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov 03 (IPS) - For many of Argentina’s voters the choice in the 19 November presidential runoff is between the lesser of two evils: Sergio Massa, economy minister of a government that’s presiding over a once-in-a-generation economic meltdown with a whopping 140-per cent inflation rate, or Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian who admires Donald Trump, wants to shut down the Central Bank and wields a chainsaw in public as a symbol of his willingness to slash the state. Many will rue that it ever came to this.

Read the full story, “Argentina: Unpalatable Choices in Election Plagued with Uncertainty”, on globalissues.org →

entry.title: Two U.S. Carrier Strike Groups Are Now Operating In The Eastern Mediterranean Sea
entry.summary:
USS Gerald R. Ford (CVN-78) steams in formation with the Nimitz-class aircraft carrier USS Dwight D. Eisenhower (CVN-69) during a photo exercise, Nov. 3, 2023. US Navy Photo
USNI News: USS Gerald R. Ford, USS Dwight D. Eisenhower Operate Together in Eastern Med. For the first time in decades, two U.S. aircraft carriers sailed together in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea, U.S. 6th fleet announced Friday.
Carriers USS Gerald R. Ford (CVN-78) and USS Dwight D. Eisenhower (CVN-69) drilled for three days in the Mediterranean Sea along with USS Mount Whitney (LCC-20) and two Italian guided-missile frigates. “Operating dual carrier strike groups alongside Allies and Partners in a dynamic environment demonstrates our capability and capacity to respond with agility decisively to any contingency,” Vice Adm. Thomas Ishee, commander of the U.S. 6th Fleet said in a Friday statement. “Our presence sends a clear signal about our commitment to deter aggression and promote stability throughout the region.”

entry.title: Ukraine shelling kills 9 in occupied south: local official

The attack occurred as Kyiv conducts a counteroffensive to regain territory from Russian forces in southern Ukraine. "Nine dead people were pulled out from under the rubble," Vladimir Saldo, the Russian-installed head of the Moscow-occupied Kherson region, told Russian state television.

entry.title: Israeli President meets with envoys whose citizens were murdered and abducted by Hamas
entry.summary: Israeli President Isaac Herzog met with the ambassadors of Thailand, the Philippines, Tanzania, and Nepal to discuss the terror invasion carried out by Hamas in southwestern Israel. The ambassadors expressed concern for their citizens who were killed, injured, or taken hostage during the attack. President Herzog emphasized that Hamas does not differentiate between religions or countries and assured the ambassadors that the Israeli people appreciate their citizens. Among foreign countries, Thailand had the second-highest number of fatalities and a significant number of citizens taken hostage by Hamas. The Thai ambassador expressed concern for the well-being of the Thai people in Israel and asked for assistance in locating and helping the abducted individuals.

Nasrallah's speech has been widely anticipated as an indication of whether the Israel-Hamas conflict could escalate into a regional war.

entry.title: Hezbollah Leader Hassan Nasrallah Warns The U.S. To Halt Israel's Gaza Attacks Or Risk A Regional War
entry.summary:
Reuters: Hezbollah tells U.S. to halt Israel's Gaza attack to prevent regional war BEIRUT (Reuters) - The leader of Lebanon's Hezbollah warned the United States on Friday that preventing a regional conflict depended on stopping the Israeli attack on Gaza, and said there was a possibility of fighting on the Lebanese front turning into a full-fledged war. Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah, in his first speech since the Israel-Hamas war erupted on Oct. 7, also threatened Israel's main ally the United States, hinting his Iran-backed group was ready to confront U.S. warships in the Mediterranean. "You, the Americans, can stop the aggression against Gaza because it is your aggression. Whoever wants to prevent a regional war, and I am talking to the Americans, must quickly halt the aggression on Gaza," Nasrallah said.

entry.title: Storm Ciaran kills 5, taking European death toll to 12
entry.summary: Record-breaking rain produced floods in a vast swath of Italy's Tuscany region as Storm Ciaran pushed into the country overnight trapping residents in their homes, inundating hospitals and overturning cars. At least five people were killed, bringing the storm's death toll in western Europe to 12 on Friday. Italian Civil Protection authorities said 200 millimeters (nearly 8 inches) of rain fell in a three-hour period, from the coastal city of Livorno to the inland valley of Mugello, and caused riverbanks to overflow. Video shows at least a dozen cars getting pushed down a flooded road.

entry.title: Bollywood superstars: Paris exhibition delves into a century of Indian cinema
entry.summary: In this special edition of Access Asia, we're at Paris's Quai Branly museum, where a new exhibition, "Bollywood superstars", looks back at a century of the Indian film industry. With more than 2,000 movies per year, Bollywood is the biggest movie industry in the world. It evolved from performing arts and silent films to today's big blockbusters. We speak to the exhibition's co-curator Julien Rousseau, as well as Mahina Khanum, a Bollywood dancer and choreographer. Plus, we explore how India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is increasingly using the country's cinema to push its Hindu nationalist agenda.

entry.title: Commonwealth Civil Society Offers Ministers Crucial Recommendations for Gender Equality Advancement
entry.summary:
SAINT LUCIA, Nov 03 (IPS) - Amid fears that global shocks like the COVID-19 pandemic have eroded progress toward gender equality, the Commonwealth Foundation has created an online platform that takes civil society’s recommendations for the empowerment of women and girls directly to policymakers.On August 22, 2023, Women's Affairs Ministers from the Commonwealth huddled in a room at the Atlantis Resort in the Bahamas. For the first time since the COVID-19 pandemic, they were meeting in person.

Blinken discussed the details of these pauses with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the war cabinet, emphasizing the need to ensure that Hamas does not exploit the pauses for its own advantage.

entry.title: Iran sentences a woman to death for adultery
entry.summary: An Iranian court has sentenced a female gym trainer to death for adultery. The woman's husband reported her to the police after finding her with another man at their home, whom he discovered through surveillance cameras. Although Iranian law allows for appeals, the country has faced international criticism for its frequent use of the death penalty. The United Nations Secretary-General, Antonio Guterres, warned that Iran was executing people at an "alarming rate." Crimes such as adultery, sodomy, murder, rape, armed robbery, kidnapping, and drug trafficking are all punishable by death in Iran.

entry.title: China jet fired flares at Canadian chopper in international waters: Ottawa
entry.summary: Canadian defence minister Bill Blair informed the press on Friday that a Chinese military aircraft discharged flares toward a Canadian helicopter in international waters the previous Sunday. He stated that Ottawa intends to communicate its concerns to Beijing. This marks the second instance within a two-week period where Canada has raised accusations of unsafe conduct by China's air force. In mid-October, Minister Blair reported that a Chinese fighter jet had approached within five meters (approximately 16 feet) of a surveillance aircraft engaged in a United Nations mission.

entry.title: Morocco unearths Roman-era second century site in Rabat
entry.summary: Archaeologists in Morocco have discovered a Roman-era site in Rabat, which includes a port district, bath, and cemetery dating back to the second century. The site, now the third largest in Morocco, will provide insights into the lives of Roman settlers and romanised Moroccans during that time. The bath covers an area of over 2000 square meters and resembles imperial counterparts in Rome. The excavation is ongoing to uncover the port and other parts of one of the largest Roman towns in the country.

entry.title: US intelligence Believes Iran And Its Proxies Are Seeking To Avoid A Wider War With Israel
entry.summary:
CNN: US intelligence currently assesses Iran and its proxies are seeking to avoid a wider war with Israel The US intelligence community believes – for now – that Iran and its proxies are calibrating their response to Israel’s military intervention in Gaza to avoid direct conflict with Israel or the US while still exacting costs on its adversaries. But the US is also keenly aware that Iran does not maintain perfect control of its umbrella of proxies – in particular over Lebanese Hezbollah, the largest and most capable of the various groups. Hezbollah is an ally of Hamas, the group that attacked Israel on October 7, and has long positioned itself as fighting against Israel. US officials are deeply concerned that the group’s internal politics may cause Hezbollah to escalate simmering tensions. The US also does not always have perfect visibility into the communications between Iran and its various proxies, according to sources familiar with US intelligence in the region.
Read more ....
WNU Editor: We shall see if Iran is committed to avoiding a wider war with Israel. But I am skeptical. I do not see any de-escalation in the Israel - Hamas war, and tensions between Israel and Hezbollah continues to remain high. The Houthis in Yemen have already declared war against Israel. It will not take much to spark this into a major regional war.

entry.title: 'Pathetic': Marjorie Taylor Greene attacks 'feckless Republicans' who voted against her
entry.summary:
She tried to censure and it came up short. Now she's shaming the names who didn't vote in favor. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) had willed a resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) for her attendance of a protest opposing the war in Gaza. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? "List of feckless Republicans that voted WITH Democrats to table my censure resolution against Rashida Tlaib," Greene said on Wednesday. "This is why Republicans NEVER do anything to stop the communists Democrats or ever hold anyone accountable!! PATHETIC."
She created a social media thread naming some of her friends in the House who didn't have what it took to vote with her. They include current House Speaker Mike Johnson, Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX), and Rep. Ken Buck (R-CO) who announced he wasn't running for reelection.
Earlier in the week, Greene preemptively lashed out after learning that her effort wasn't gaining a coalition in Congress. "I want to remind you, this happened on the same day Hezbollah declared a day of immense anger," she said. "And Rashida Tlaib organized with that group. And they did. They did protest, and they did an insurrection into our Capitol complex, stopping Congress and stopping the Senate." The media was quick to take notice of the lawmaker's swing and miss Wednesday. "Colleague Kelly Phares rpts 23 GOPers join Dems to table or kill effort to censure Dem MI Rep Tlaib," tweeted Chat Pergram. Melanie Zanona also tweeted: "motion to table — aka kill — MTG’s resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib just passed the House, with help of 23 Republicans."
And CNN's Manu Raju added that the effort to take on Tlaib quickly died tweeting: "House kills resolution to censure Rashida Tlaib. 23 Republicans voted with Dems. MTG offered the resolution."

entry.title: Republicans to join Dems in breaking Tuberville's blockade on military promotions: report
entry.summary: Sen. Tommy Tuberville's (R-AL) blockade appears to be coming to an end, according to an MSNBC report. Capitol reporter Ali Vitali said that a group of Republicans were going to take to the Senate floor and force a vote with Democrats to marginalize Tuberville's protest against military promotions that has led to a reduced military readiness for the United States, according to reports. After a discussion about the absurdity of the protest, host Nicolle Wallace said that she recalled the era when Republicans had to be supportive of the military or they'd be shamed by leaders like Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and the GOP speaker. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? Taking to social media, reporter Andrew Desiderio confirmed the reporting, saying that the floor actions will take place tonight, where they will ask for unanimous consent on ending the Tuberville blockade. He said that he was told it would be led by Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-AK). The news comes after reports that McConnell threatened Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) over his bill to stop corporations from being able to give money to campaigns. McConnell reportedly pointed to Hawley in the caucus lunch and said he wouldn't be there if it wasn't for the money from his Senate Leadership PAC. He went on to threaten any member who supported the bill with a primary. It's the first such action heard about from McConnell since he suffered serious injuries from a series of falls and then appeared to freeze at various public press availabilities.

entry.title: Tuberville's military blockade has 'added danger' after top Marine's heart attack: report
entry.summary: He drew a hard line in the sand, stalling hundreds of promotions of military brass. That line is budging. Officials are fuming at Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) after it was discovered over the weekend that Marine Corps Commandant Gen. Eric Smith, who had been doubling as both the top No. 1 and No. 2 Marine Corps leader since July, suffered an apparent heart attack and was hospitalized on Sunday — leaving a three-star general to hold the prestigious post, according to a report published by Politico. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? The potential overextension of Smith and the stalling of more than 300 critical leadership roles was iced out by Tuberville's blockade installed as a protest against the Pentagon's policy to permit time off and reimbursement for abortions. Now…

Reporters Without Borders, or RSF, filed a complaint with the International Criminal Court on Tuesday, asking its prosecutors to investigate the death of eight Palestinian journalists killed by Israeli forces amid bombardments of civilian areas in Gaza, and of one Israeli journalist killed while covering an attack on his kibbutz by Hamas on Oct. 7. entry.summary: House Speaker Mike Johnson told Republican senators behind closed doors Wednesday that he supports more funding for Ukraine if it's connected with tougher southern border security, and that aid for Israel should come separately, according to lawmakers in the room.

When the aggression started in full swing, many people in the world expected that Ukraine would not hold out," Zelensky said in his daily address late on Tuesday. entry.title: Spain's Princess Leonor swears allegiance to divided nation on her 18th birthday
entry.summary: By David Latona MADRID (Reuters) - Princess Leonor, the heir to Spain's throne, formally stepped into the spotlight by swearing allegiance to the constitution on her 18th birthday on Tuesday, though boycotts by leftist and separatist politicians underlined divisions over the monarchy. The ceremony in parliament marked her coming of age, meaning she will now directly become queen after her father King Felipe VI, assuming he does not go on to have any male children. The princess, who went to school in Wales and started three years of military training in Spain in August, vowed to uphold the law,...

entry.title: Dominican Republic allows some Haiti flights as OAS arrives to meet about border dispute

Hamas militants carried out a shock cross-border attack from Gaza this month that Israeli officials say killed more than 1,400 people, prompting Washington to rush military aid to Israel and sparking fears in Kyiv that backing for its war against invading Russian forces could suffer. Salvadorean port authorities said that the measure would be applied to passengers in transit earlier this month, and that the tariffs were for “airport improvements” as more passengers were entering, leaving, and connecting through San Salvador this year compared to previous ones. “The Government of President Nayib Bukele is working...

Nasim Abu Ajina "directed the massacre on October 7th in the Kibbutz Erez and Moshav Netiv HaAsara," the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) and the Israeli Security Agency (ISA) said in a joint statement posted on Telegram. "In the past, Abu Ajina commanded Hamas' Aerial Array, and took part in the development of the UAVs and paragliders of the terrorist organization," the statement continued. entry.title: How Nicaragua is helping – and charging – Haitians who want to reach the United States
entry.summary: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti – Across the street from the departure terminal at Toussaint Louverture International Airport in Haiti’s gang-plagued capital, hundreds of anxious travelers spill out onto the road from an overflowing parking lot, listening for their Nicaragua-bound flight to be called. As ticket agents in white shirts walk through the chaotic crowd, there is chatter about how many days some have been camping out and the desperation driving them to Managua, the new migration springboard for migrants seeking asylum in the United States. “There is nowhere that is simple,” one young man says...

entry.title: Britain's King Charles begins Kenya visit steeped in 'painful' colonial history
entry.summary: By Duncan Miriri NAIROBI (Reuters) - Britain's King Charles begins a four-day state visit to Kenya on Tuesday, his first to a former colony, during which he plans to acknowledge "painful aspects" of a shared history that included almost seven decades of colonial rule. Accompanied by Queen Camilla, Charles arrived in the East African country overnight and will be received by Kenyan President William Ruto in the capital Nairobi on Tuesday morning. Buckingham Palace says the visit is a reflection of the two countries' close cooperation on economic development, climate change and security issues. ...

entry.summary: By Mayela Armas and Vivian Sequera CARACAS (Reuters) - Venezuela's Supreme Justice Tribunal said on Monday it has suspended the results of an opposition presidential primary that took place this month, despite an electoral deal between the government and the opposition that allows each side to choose its candidate. The ruling could risk the wrath of the United States, which this month rolled back some oil and gas industry and bond trading sanctions in exchange for the electoral deal. The U.S. State Department has already said it will reinstate sanctions if the government of President Nicolas M...

entry.title: Kenyans urge King Charles III to formally apologize for colonial-era abuses

Calls are growing for the British monarch to make a heartfelt apology for colonial era abuses as he and Queen Camilla tour the east African country. The tour is the first to a Commonwealth country since he succeeded his late mother, Queen Elizabeth, who died in September after a seven-decade reign. Buckingham Palace announced that King Charles would “acknowledge the more painful aspects of the U.K. and Kenya’s shared history,” which includes the bloody Mau Mau rebellion of the...

Israel has expanded ground operations in Gaza as it seeks to punish Hamas for a deadly gun rampage three weeks ago that Israeli authorities say killed over 1,400 people. The gathering, set to be attended by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, US Vice President Kamala Harris, EU chief Ursula von der Leyen and UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, will focus on growing fears about the implications of so-called frontier AI. entry.title: Heavy rains cause partial dam collapse, flooding in Norway
entry.summary: Storm Hans battered Norway with heavy rains Tuesday and Wednesday. Flooding of the Braskereidfoss power dam control room prevented the hatches from opening, causing a partial collapse and flooding downriver. The heavy rains provoked mudslides and swollen rivers which swept away some structures and flooded towns, requiring the evacuation of more than 3,000 people and isolating others.

entry.summary: Wildfires fanned by the winds of a distant hurricane devastated Hawaii's Maui island on Wednesday, killing at least six people, Maui County Mayor Richard Bissen said at a news conference.

entry.summary: A fire ripped through a vacation home for adults with disabilities in eastern France on Wednesday, killing 11 people, officials said.

entry.title: Former Iran ambassador to Moscow: Tehran must take Russia’s use of fake name for Persian Gulf seriously
entry.summary: Iran’s former ambassador to Moscow says Russia’s recent stance on the Persian Gulf’s name is a new development that must be taken seriously.

entry.title: More US lawmakers join boycott of Israeli president’s speech to Congress
entry.summary: Three more US lawmakers have announced their intentions to boycott Israeli President Isaac Herzog's address to a joint session of Congress next week. It comes after Congresswoman Ilhan Omar announced there would be "no way in hell" she would be in attendance.

entry.title: EU extends humanitarian exemption for Syria for another six months
entry.summary: The Council of the European Union has announced that it was extending humanitarian exemption from sanctions against Syria, which was introduced in February after the devastating earthquake hit the war-torn country.

entry.title: UNICEF says 11 children die every week attempting to cross Mediterranean migration route
entry.summary: During the first half of the current year, 289 boys and girls died while crossing the Mediterranean Sea to reach Europe, or double the number compared to the same period in 2022, the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF) has announced.

entry.title: World Bank says Iran ranks 1st in drinking water access in urban, rural regions
entry.summary: The World Bank has announced in a report that Iran ranks first in terms of access to drinking water in urban and rural areas across the globe and among countries in the West Asia region.

entry.title: Iraq ramps up deployment of guards on Kurdistan region after Iran’s warning about terrorists
entry.summary: Iraq has ramped up the deployment of its guards on the Kurdistan region’s border with Iran. It comes after Tehran warned that Baghdad government’s failure to deal with anti-Iran terrorists will prompt fresh attacks.

entry.title: Iran’s top military commander meets with Pakistan’s Army chief
entry.summary: Major General Mohammad Baqeri, the chief of staff of Iran’s Armed Forces, has met with Pakistan’s Army Chief General Asim Munir.

entry.title: US plans to send F-16 jets to Persian Gulf
entry.summary: A senior US defence official has confirmed that Washington is deploying additional fighter jets around the strategic Strait of Hormuz "to protect ships from Iranian seizures". The Islamic Revolution Guards Corps (IRGC) says Iranian naval forces have so far seized 35 ships for violating maritime laws in the waters off the Persian Gulf.

entry.title: Most Powerful Man competition held in Iran’s Zanjan
entry.summary: A competition has been held to identify the most powerful man in Zanjan Province, in Iran’s northwest.

entry.title: South Africa should follow intl. law if Putin visits Johannesburg: ICC chief prosecutor
entry.summary: South Africa should do "the right thing" and follow international law if Russian President Vladimir Putin attends the BRICS bloc summit in Johannesburg next month in person, International Criminal Court (ICC) Chief Prosecutor Karim Khan told CNN. In mid-March, the ICC issued arrest warrants for Putin and Maria Lvova-Belova, the Russian presidential commissioner for children’s rights over the Ukraine war.

entry.title: Beijing’s envoy: China backs Iran’s bid to join BRICS
entry.summary: China’s ambassador to Iran says his country supports the Islamic Republic’s bid to join the BRICS group of emerging economies.

entry.title: Iran’s Leader offers condolences to Hezbollah chief over demise of Muslim scholar
entry.summary: Leader of the Islamic Revolution Ayatollah Seyyed Ali Khamenei has extended his condolences to the Hezbollah Secretary-General Seyyed Hassan Nasrallah over the passing of a religious authority and Shia scholar from Lebanon.

entry.title: Iran tourism: Sahoolan water cave, West Azerbaijan Province
entry.summary: Sahoolan is a cave in a village with the same name located 42 kilometers southeast of the city of Mahabad, in Iran’s West Azerbaijan Province.

entry.title: Israel sets record for illegal settler units approvals: Rights group
entry.summary: Israel’s far-right government has approved record construction in illegal settlements in the occupied West Bank in its first six months in power, Al-Jazeera reported quoting an Israeli rights group.

entry.title: Wagner was never a legal entity: Kremlin
entry.summary: The Kremlin has announced that the Wagner private mercenary group, which led a "failed insurrection against Russian President Vladimir Putin" last month, was never a legal entity and that its legal status needs further consideration.

entry.title: Live Update: Russia’s “Special Operation” in Ukraine; Day 507
entry.summary: Russia, wary of NATO’s eastward expansion, began a military campaign in Ukraine in February 2022 after the Western-leaning Kiev government turned a deaf ear to Moscow’s calls for its neighbor to maintain its neutrality. entry.title: Removal of fishing ban in northern Iranian village, long-time tradition
entry.summary: Balabisheh Sar village is in Babol’s central district and the Feyzieh County in the northern Iranian province of Mazandaran.

entry.title: Hundreds seek medical help due to dust storm in southeastern Iranian province
entry.summary: An official in Iran’s southeastern Sistan and Baluchestan Province says around 600 people have sought medical help following a dust storm with strong winds hitting parts of the province.

entry.title: Iran very sensitive to claims about three Persian Gulf islands: Army commander
entry.summary: Major General Abdolrahim Mousavi, the commander-in-chief of Iran’s Army, says the country is very sensitive to claims made about its three islands in the Persian Gulf, to which the United Arab Emirates lays claims.

entry.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?
entry.summary:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated. Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…

entry.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
entry.summary:
Getty Images
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…

entry.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live
entry.summary:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth. In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters. The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…

entry.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment
entry.summary:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023. | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising. Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…

entry.title: Why retailers are bullish on New York's luxury hallways
entry.summary: Midtown is booming, brokers say, thanks to the return of office workers and tourists. “We are totally back,” said Steven Soutendijk, executive managing director at Cushman & Wakefield. Retailers around Midtown office corridors “live and die with office density, and we’re seeing a noticeable difference,” said David LaPierre, vice president of CBRE. Now, there doesn’t seem to be a shortage of old and new concepts. “It’s like the city and retailers have woken up,” said Jared Epstein, president and chief executive of Aurora Capital Associates. “We had stock on just about everything from Soho to the Meatpacking District, West Village, Midtown and Brooklyn. There’s clothing, food, fitness, healthcare, and interest at every level, with spaces filling up fast. At Madison Avenue on the Upper …
